userreviews.userReview: I woke up, excited to read this book that had just came to me from one of my #bookexpedition mates. I grabbed it, went downstairs and, coffee in hand, got to reading. I did nothing else until I finished. No food, no shower. I was absorbed.I'm not sure there's any such thing as a "perfect" book. But if there is, for this time in which we are living, for me, Harbor Me is perfect. From her first line - "We think they took my papi." - to the lyricism of Woodson's writing, I was immediately drawn into the world of 6 kids. Haley, Holly, Amari, Esteban, Tiago, and Ashton, each have their own stories. Their stories are slowly, patiently revealed by Woodson as the kids spend an hour every Friday afternoon of school in ARTT - A Room to Talk. As their stories are revealed, each so different, they find friendship, community, self-worth, and a harbor. The story's ending is not what I thought it would be but, upon reflection, there's no other way it could have ended given our current political climate.Woodson pulls no punches. Topics that belong in every classroom - racism, immigration, police brutality - are all in this book, and they are all at a level that kids can understand, and about which they can develop both empathy critical thinking. I want to do nothing but teach this book in my classroom next year. I can't wait until it comes out so I can buy copies for my fellow teachers. Bravo, Ms. Woodson. Thank you for writing this.

I started this book before bed and had to read it first thing this morning. Jackie Woodson spoke to my heart with this one. In this crazy, at times unrecognizable world we are living in, we need to harbor each other. We need to be there to listen, to protect, to care for and love each other. Harbor Me is the story of six students in 5/6th grade who are brought together because of their school related needs. Their teacher gives them a gift of uninterrupted time, on their own, once a week in a special room to share their stories. At first the kids aren’t sure what to do with the ARTT (A Room To Talk) time. But as they get to know each other, as they open up and speak their truth, it becomes their safe space, a haven for their worried minds and hurting hearts. This is an important and beautiful book by the always amazing Jacqueline Woodson and published by the incredible Nancy Paulsen. What a gift to the middle grade world! Comes out in late August.

I started reading this book expecting to love it, as I have loved everything I’ve ever read by Jaqueline Woodson, I was not disappointed.Her combination of characters and their stories weaves together an amazing and timely tale of what life is like for so many young people in our country. The support they give each other and the love they have for each other really touched my heart.This middle grade novel is sure to become an important story for so many young people.

Beautiful, heartfelt, impactful, and necessary. A community building type of story, this book begs to be shared. It is a must for school and classroom libraries, and I'll be sharing with my 4/5 teachers to consider as a whole class read aloud.

Thank you Jacqueline Woodson and Nancy Paulsen. The message is timely in our national political climate currently. Today, I want to be a loving, listening, and caring harbor in our elementary library. Such an inspiring middle-grade book for our time.

Loved it. Heartfelt, honest, emotional, timely..... a story of the human struggles we see on TV everyday (immigration, racism, poverty, bullying) told through the voices of several middle schoolers. Jackie Woodson is a master at writing prose like poetry - I'll read anything by her.
Reserving review until closer to the release of the book. This is one you will want to be reading at the beginning of the new school year.

There are so many heavy topics covered in this novel such as immigration, racism, privilege, and parental loss. I was mesmerized by the characters and I can't get over how brilliant this story is. Haley's use of the recorder to remember her friends confessions was perfect. I love how Woodson weaved the stories so beautifully making every situation relevant to our society today.

Readers may find that Jackie Woodson is at the top of her game and Harbor Me may be one of her best pieces of middle grade fiction. It is honest and does an outstanding job of demonstrating how important peer relationships are to young people and how helpful they can be in order to work through personal problems.The school intervention specialist teacher sends her class of six students to a separate classroom for an hour on Friday afternoons to talk among themselves about issues that are bothering them in their daily life. There are no adults present to judge/guide/advise. Most important is that they must obey the “rules” – including what may be the most important one: to be kind in their remarks. During the course of the year, the diverse group bonds, learning to open up, to trust, and to understand each other, forming potentially life-long friendships. It all begins with Esteban, who talks about his father who was recently taken to Florida by Immigration and Customs Enforcement – “We think they took my papi.” Other discussions center on racial profiling, bullying, poverty, experiencing the loss of a parent, what it is like having a father in prison, what it’s like to have a disability, feeling bias due to language barriers, and first crushes.Woodson takes her characters on a roller coaster ride of highs and lows with great care and tenderness. They are respectful of each other, calling those out who “label” someone. It is interesting that she never really identifies what the disabilities are that the students have, as only one expresses how difficult it is to sit still and focus. Readers will identify with all of them, as they may see themselves or their friends in the story, and weep as she poignantly walks this group through some of the tough life issues they have to deal with. The writing is lyric and musical in many places and the pacing is just right.Recommended for grades 5-8.

I received an ARC copy of this book. I thought this book did an amazing job approaching a variety of heavy topics that can be difficult for middle grade youth. In a Breakfast Club style approach, 6 youth in grades 5 and 6 of different cultural and socioeconomic backgrounds spend an hour once a week alone in a classroom to simply talk. Their teacher recognized that they had things they were aching to discuss, but would need the privacy and encouragement of a safe place to talk without adults around.Some of the topics these kids discuss include deportation of immigrants, police brutality, racial profiling, privilege, unfair aspects of the justice system, settlement/conquest, blended families, biracial identity, the stigma of learning disabilities, ESL, and bullying. These topics are discussed in varying degrees, offering different perspectives and beliefs. Woodson does an amazing job of broaching these topics in a relevant way that I feel middle grade readers can relate to in one way or another. There is room for debate and disagreement in the safe environment that the characters have cultivated.

Jacqueline Woodson’s gift of words trick us into thinking the poetry oozing out of its pages at every turn magically appear, that we, too, can wield a mighty pen like a laden paintbrush and produce a masterpiece. Don’t be fooled, dear reader. That is why she is who she is, and we are...well, not.Console yourself in the knowledge that she holds a mirror up to us, to society, to our students. We are lucky that we can tuck her books into the hands and hearts of our kids and whisper to them, “You are seen. You are not alone.” Harbor Us will tie in nicely with our yearlong study of immigration, migrant farmers and Angel Island.This sweet story of six classmates, one uncle and a father locked far away is the pinnacle of Woodson’s love letter to our kids. I can’t wait for our children to read it.*Thanks to Edelweiss-Above the Treeline for the sneak peek.

I was given this book to read and review as part of the #bookexpedition group.Knowing I needed to read it fairly quickly to pass on to other group members, I struggled. Woodson’s writing is so beautiful, so powerful, I wanted to savor each word, sentence, and paragraph. The story is told from the perspective of Haley, one of the six students who spends time in the ARTT room every Friday afternoon. Each student has a story that unfolds, and current events topics are discussed from the students’ perspectives. I’ve already preordered this book and I’ll be using as a read aloud with my 5th grade students in the fall. I’m looking forward to the discussion it’s sure to bring on issues such as immigration and power.

This book. Sooooo wonderful. Six kids in a classroom doing their thing, until their teacher gives them a weekly time to just talk. In a room, unsupervised. The result is raw, real, and wonderful. Each of the kids has their own struggles to navigate, and for the most part they're doing ok. But with the small group dynamic they build, they actually start to thrive. They become thinking, wondering, curious kids who look out for one another like they haven't before. They become a little family, sharing heartbreaks and joy. This book is Humanity 101.This will be a read aloud in my classroom as soon as it's published. Every classroom should have it, every child should read it, and every adult should read it as well. Beautiful.

Beautifully written and brings all the feels! 6 5th graders, struggling with school and life, get a chance to connect in a safe place. The idea of being a safe harbor for one another, where they can talk about their fears and daily struggles- loss, incarceration, deportation, bullying, the realities of racism and prejudices. A powerful look at what can happen when we come together and really connect on a deeper level.

This is the book we need right now. Immigration and race relations tied into a beautiful story of friendships. #harborme @penguinkids @jackiewoodson Special thanks to Nancy Paulsen for sending this beautiful uncorrected galley. Due out August 2018

Such a timely book. Woodson weaves the lives of six kids with stories of compassion, pain, love, and friendship. Maybe the world would be a different place if we would let kids go to A Room To Talk and learn to harbor one another. Maybe...just maybe.
Beautiful novel, I read the manuscript one sitting. It gave me goosebumps.
Woodson packs a lot into this slim, readable volume - intense friendship and family crises, assumptions, bullying. Earnest and heartfelt. Important addition to any collection.
Beautiful, heartbreaking and warming and then breaking again, but in that good way that lets your muscles grow.
Beautiful and timely.
Prepare to cry and hug the book and then cry again.

Her first middle grade novel since Brown Girl Dreaming, Harbor Me is a beautiful book of friendships forged during troubled times, a reminder that life may break your heart but, more importantly, it can show you how to mend it together again.

description: Jacqueline Woodson's first middle-grade novel since National Book Award winner Brown Girl Dreaming celebrates the healing that can occur when a group of students share their stories.It all starts when six kids have to meet for a weekly chat—by themselves, with no adults to listen in. There, in the room they soon dub the ARTT Room (short for "A Room to Talk"), they discover it's safe to talk about what's bothering them—everything from Esteban's father's deportation and Haley's father's incarceration to Amari's fears of racial profiling and Ashton's adjustment to his changing family fortunes. When the six are together, they can express the feelings and fears they have to hide from the rest of the world. And together, they can grow braver and more ready for the rest of their lives.
title: Harbor Me
